text: Blue, deep and featureless, the twilight of five hundred  feet down. PROPELLER SOUND.  Materializing out of the blue limbo is enormous but sleek form of an Ohio-class SSBN ballistic  missile submarine.
In the attack center, darkened to womb-red, the crew's fa shine with sweat in the glow of their instruments.  The  SKIPPER and his EXEC crowd around BARNES, the sonarman.
Sixty knots?  No way, Barnes... the  reds don't have anything that fast.

Checked it twice, skipper.  It's a  real unique signature.  No cavitation,  no reactor noise...  doesn't even  sound like screws. He puts the signal onto a speaker and everyone in the att room listens to the intruder's acoustic signature, a stra THRUMMING.  The captain studies the electronic position b a graphic representation of the contours of the steep-wal canyon, a symbol for the Montana, and converging with it, amorphous trace, representing the bogey.
What the hell is it?
I'll tell you what it's not, it's  not one of ours.
Sir!  Contact changing heading to  two-one-four, diving.  Speed eighty  knots!  Eighty knots!
Eighty knots...
Still diving, depth nine hundred  feet.  Port clearance to cliff wall,  one hundred fifty feet.
(simultaneously)

Still diving, depth nine hundred  feet.  Port clearance to cliff wall,  one hundred fifty feet. Tension builds in the attack room as the Montana surges t intercept theY intruder.  The exec tensely watches the ve graphic readout for the side-scan sonar array.  The sub i running uncomfortably close to the cliff walls.
(low, to Captain)
It's getting tight in here.
We can still give him a haircut.   Helm, come right to oh six niner,  down five degrees.
Coming right to oh six niner, sir.   Down five degrees.
Port side clearance one hundred twenty  feet narrowing to seventy-five.   Sir, we have a proximity warning  light.
That's too damn close!  We've gotta  back off.
Range to contact, two hundred.   Contact junked to bearing two six oh  and accelerated to... one hundred  thirty knots, sir!
(really freaked now)
Nothing goes one thirty! Suddenly the control room lights dim almost to blackness.
We see only the effect, not the source, as a large diffus light passes rapidly under the sub's hull.  Moments later shockwave, like an underwater sonic boom, impacts the sub slamming it sideways.
The bridge crew are knocked off their feet, as the ship i buffeted.
Turbulence!  We're in its wake! SIRENS.  Everyone shouting at once.  The power flickers l
Helm, all stop!  Full right rudder!

All stop.  Full right rudder.   Hydraulic failure.  Planes are not  responding, sir! Power returns in time for the sonarman to get a glimpse a the side-scan display... AS THE SHEER CLIFF WALL LOOM BEF THEM.
Hydraulics restored, sir.

The cliff wall materializes out of the blue limbo off the port bow with nightmarish slow-motion.  The sub slams int it with horrific force, scraping along and bouncing off. One tail stabilizer is sheared off and the big screw pran the wall with an earsplitting K-K-KWANG!

With the outer tube-doors torn off, seawater slams in, bu the inner hatches.  Two-foot thick columns of water, like fire-hoses of the gods, blast into the room.  Everything  vanishes instantly in white spray.
Everyone is hurled off his feet.  The planesman flights t recover control of the yoke.
Collision alarm!  Collision alarm!   Lighten her up, Charlie!
The torpedo room is flooded, sir!
Blow all tanks!  Blow everything!
Passing twelve hundred feet...
Blowing main tanks!
Twelve hundred fifty feet...
The great sub is being hauled down by the mass of its flo bow section, its flanks rushing past us like a freight tr headed for Hell.
The command crew fights futilely for control, everyone  shouting and terrified.
Main forward tanks ruptured!
Passing thirteen hundred feet...
Too deep to pump auxiliaries!
All back full!  All back full!
Answering all back full.  Passing  thirteen hundred fifty feet...  fourteen hundred... fourteen fifty... The Captain locks eyes with the Exec amid the din...
We're losing her.  Launch the buoy! The Exec opens the door to a small box and punches a butt A red light comes on.  The Captain takes a deep breath.
A tiny transmitter is ejected from the sub's hell and beg its long ascent to the surface.  A second later the sub s down like a piledriver onto a ledge, tearing open its pre hull.

VARIOUS QUICK CUTS, just flashes and impressions, as... Seawater blasts down the corridors -- Explodes across the control room, hurling men like dolls Floods the cavernous missile bay in seconds -- Bursts through hatches into the reactor room -- Blasts men OUT OF FRAME in a micro-second.

In the cobalt twilight we see the Montana slide down the cliff, its hull SCREECHING like the death agonies of some marine dinosaur.  Descending in an avalanche of silt, it  finally disappears into the blackness below... a blacknes which continues almost straight down, 20,000 feet to the  bottom of the Cayman Trough.  The abyss.
Above, in the world, the Caribbean rolling gray under a s sky.  The Montana's emergency buoy pops to the surface,  transmitting.

LONG LENS SHOT: three massive Navy Sea King helicopters  thundering straight at us, FILLING FRAME. REVERSE, as they barrel OVER CAMERA toward a lone civilia ship... an ugly but very sophisticated deep-sea drilling  support ship, the BENTHIC EXPLORER. It is a twin-hulled monstrosity with a central opening in its deck, around which crouch enormous cranes, winches an other arcane equipment. The first Sea King settles onto the helipad, disgorging a contingent of Naval officers, technicians, and a squad of armed seamen.  A pantomime in the rotorwash, we see the  Benthic Petroleum "company man" KIRKHILL greeting COMMODO DEMARCO, the on-scene commander.
The bridge is state-of-the-art, with computers and  sophisticated navigation and communications gear, looking
like mission control with its bank of video monitors.  Th Drilling Operations Supervisor, LELAND MCBRIDE, and BENDI the crew chief, watch the invaders swarming the deck belo

Does not look good at all. TIGHT ON VIDEO SCREEN (MINUTES LATER) showing divers work in total blackness around some sort of installation on th bottom of the ocean.  They move through the harsh floodli in dreamlike slow motion, looking like space-suited figur with their helmets and umbilical hoses.
No light from the surface.  How deep  are they?

Seventeen hundred feet. WIDER, showing the Navy contingent crowding the control r DeMarco is hardcore military, brusque and efficient.  Kir is a small man with pinched features, wearing a shirt and tie, which on a drill ship means company man and/or dickh
I need them to go to over two  thousand.
They can do it. (to McBride)
Get Brigman on the line.

1700 FEET BELOW.  A submersible oil-drilling platform,  DEEPCORE II, an island of light in the vast blackness.  I main framework connects two "tri-modules" consisting of t cylinders each.  These contain living and work areas in a pressurized environment.  An umbilical cable, thick as a  man's thigh, runs up from the oil rig into the darkness, the Benthic Explorer at the surface.  In a bubble-like do port window we see the rig foreman, or "toolpusher," BUD  BRIGMAN.  He's talking (via headset) with two divers work outside... 'CATFISH' DE VRIES, AND LEW 'BIRD-DOG' FINLER.
Hey, you guys are milking that job.
(Kentucky drawl)
That's cause we love freezin' our  butts off out here sooo much, boss.

Bud turns from the window and crosses the drill floor.  T working heart of the rig.  THUNDEROUS MECHANICAL ROAR.  T drill crew, in hardhats and mud-plastered overalls, tend massive spinning turn-table in the center of the chamber. The semi-automated system requires only five men to opera The others are LUPTON MCWHIRTER, DWIGHT PERRY, JAMMER WIL and TOMMY RAY DIETZ.  Bud hears his names called above th din by Jammer, a massive roughneck/diver who stands a goo head taller than the rest.
(yelling)
Bud!  Hippy's on the bitch-box.   It's a call from topside.  That new  company man.
Kirkhill?  That guy doesn't know his  butt from a rathole.  Hey, Perry! One of the roustabouts, a wiry Texan, turns to him.

Do me a favor and square away the  mud hose and those cable slings.   This place is starting to look like  my apartment. Perry chuckles and sets to the task cheerfully.  Bud EXIT ducking his head through a low watertight hatch.
Bud tromps down the narrow corridor, his work boots gongi on steel.

head_text.subj: BUD, PICK UP THE TOPSIDE LINE URGENT.

text: I'm coming.  Keep your pantyhose on. He enters his office, a tiny cubicle with stacks of paper dust-gathering tech manuals and waterstained Penthouse fo outs.  He picks up the phone... punches down a line.
Brigman here.  Kirkhill?  What's  going on? (pause)
I am calm.  I'm a calm person.  Is  there some reason why I shouldn't be  calm? HOLD ON Bud's expression, darkening, as he listens.

The control module is a long narrow cabin like the inside a Winnebago, packed with instrumentation.  At the end is small bay with multiple viewports.  Outside, at a 'Christ tree' pipe installation, a lone diver can be seen welding He is accompanied by a large submersible, FLATBED, and by Remotely Operated Vehicle, or ROV, call LITTLE GEEK.  Lit Geek is an underwater robot which operated on the end of cable-like control TETHER. It has a single video 'eye' in front, by which the operat pilots the little machine.  The rig's ROV pilots is ALLEN 'HIPPY' CARNES, who stands by the window twiddling his  joysticks and drinking coffee.  His pet white rat, BEANY, crawls contentedly around his shoulders.  The door BANGS  OPEN. Hippy jumps, slops his coffee.  Bud strides in.  Not calm
Son of a bitch. He kicks a chair out of the way and slams his palm down o switch marked DIVER RECALL.  A SIREN, blasting through th water from a big hydrophone loudspeaker.
All divers.  Drop what you're doing.   Everybody out of the pool.

Flatbed's pilot, LISA 'ONE NIGHT' STANDING, can be clearl seen behind a bubble canopy.  She is a no-nonsense lady w holds her own in the mostly male environment by being one the best submersible drivers in the business.  She contro a hydraulic manipulator arm, assisting the diver, ARLISS  'SONNY' DAWSON, in his work.  Little Geek hovers around t like a tiny helicopter.  One Night moves the Flatbed arm Sonny and hands him the pipe.
Here you go, hon'.
Just in time, sugar. They react to Bud's recall, looking toward him up in the  control module.
Dammit, we just got out here.
There was a time when I would have  asked why. One Night makes a grab for his butt with the manipulator  claw, which he narrowly avoids.

Flatbed moves underneath the rig, a few feet above the  seafloor, with Sonny riding on its top deck.  It passes u a lit opening and rises toward the surface of the water i the chamber above.  Little Geek follows like an obedient  dog.

The opening is called the moonpool, and Deepcore's  submersibles are launched through it.  From inside the su bay it looks just like a swimming pool. Flatbed surfaces, nearly filling it.  The chamber also  contains CAB ONE, a similar submersible.  Jammer, Perry, some of the other drill-room boys are helping the divers of the water.  The water at this depth is only about six  degrees above freezing, and these folks are cold and prun fingered.  Finler pulls off his demand-helmet, revealing round, boyish face.
What's goin' on?  How come we got  recalled?
Hell if I know. One Night jumps 'ashore' from Flatbed's broad deck and jo them.  Catfish is unzipping his bulky dry-suit.
Just follow standard procedure, will  ya...  flog the dog till somebody  tells us what's happening.
Hey, Catfish, I'll sell you my October  Penthouse for twenty bucks.
Save your money, darlin'... the pages  are all stuck together by now. Bud enters, approaching the group.
What's goin' on, Boss?
Folks, I've just been told to shut  down the hole and prepare to move  the rig.
She-hit.

We're being asked to cooperate in a  matter of national security.  Now  you know exactly as much as I do.   So just get your gear off and get up  to control.  There's some kind of  briefing in ten minutes.
The whole rig crew is somehow jammed into the room for th video briefing. DeMarco is on the main monitor, with his aides and Kirkhi visible b.g.

At 09:22 local time this morning, an  American nuclear submarine, the USS  Montana, with 156 men aboard, went  down 22 miles from here.  There has  been no contact with the sub since  then.  The cause of the incident is  not known. PAN AROUND the reactions of the various drill crew member shocked, hushed, curious.
Your company has authorized the Navy's  use of this facility for a rescue  operation.  The code name is Operation  Salvor.
You want us to search for the sub?

No.  We know where it is.  But she's  in 2000 feet of water and we can't  reach her.  We need divers to enter  the sub and search for survivors, if  any. Bud's scowl has been deepening since DeMarco started to t
Don't you guys have your own stuff  for this type of thing?

By the time we get our rescue  submersible here the storm front  will be right on us.  But you can  get your rig in under the storm and  be on-site in fifteen hours.  That  makes you our best option right now. Hippy, born suspicious and recently graduated to paranoid leans forward...
Why should we risk our butts on a  job like this?
We have been authorized to offer you  all special-duty bonuses equivalent  to three times normal dive pay.
Hell, for triple time I'd crawl  through razor blades and shower off  with lime juice.
I'm here to tell ya', you could set  me on fire and call me names.
Look, I don't know what kind of a  deal you guys worked out with the  company, but my people are not  qualified for this... they're oil  workers.
A four-man SEAL team will transfer  down to you to supervise the  operation.

You can send down whoever you like,  but I'm the toolpusher on this rig,  and when it comes to the safety of  these people, there's me... then  there's God.  Understand?  If things  get dicey, I'm pulling the plug.
I think we're all on the same  wavelength, Brigman.  Now let's get  the wellhead uncoupled, shall we?
Bud stands beside the hatchway as the others file out tow their tasks. They comment gravely as they pass...
When Lindsey finds out about this,  it's not gonna be a pretty sight.
They're going to have to shoot her  with a tranquilizer gun.
A single Navy Sea King churns through the rain under mass thunderheads. The sea below is whipped by the storm.

PANNING ALONG BOOTED FEET, four pairs of black military s twelves line up, onto... a pair of Charles Jourdans fives under shapely ankles. WIDER, revealing the four-man team of Navy SEALs.  And a  slender woman in her early thirties.  She's attractive, i bit hardened, dressed conservatively in a skirt and jacke Meet LINDSEY.  Project Engineer for Deepcore.  She's a pa in the ass, but you'll like her.  Eventually. She's holding on grimly, sitting crammed in with the SEAL and a bunch of gear, getting tossed around by the storm. The SEALs are dressed alike in black fatigues.  They are  muscular, finely-tuned and extremely dangerous special-fo types.  The leader of the SEAL team, LIEUTENANT COFFEY, m his way forward to the cockpit. The pilot is white-knuckling his stick, trying to hold th great beast of a helicopter in position.  Through the  windshield, the deck of the Benthic Explorer can be seen  below, pitching in a violent sea.
No way I'm putting her down.  I  shouldn't even be flying in this  shit.
(cool)

Just hold it over the deck. Coffey goes back to the crew deck, moving easily in the  bucking craft.  He nods to the others SEALs, MONK, WILHIT and SCHOENICK.  In the open side door, Wilhite clips a 10 foot nylon rope to the airframe and throws out the coil. One by one the shoulder the gear-bags, grab the rope, and step out. Lindsey stands swaying in the chopper door, watching the  SEALs fast-roping to the deck.  One, two, three.  Coffey  looks at her.

You want to be on that ship, there's  only one way it's going to happen. He's sure she won't go for it.  It's his certainty that g her.  She sets her jaw.  Opening her purse she takes out small plastic bag, puts her shoes and purse in the bag, a grips the bag in her teeth.  Then grabs the rope and slid down.

Swinging wildly in the wind like a human pendulum, Lindse fast-ropes forty feet to the deck.  She steps away an ins before Coffey hits behind her. Lindsey crosses the rainswept deck with athletic strides. Her nylons are ruined.  An air-crewman in the chopper low two additional equipment cases using the rescue sling.  T SEALs catch them as they swing radically across the deck. They Navy chopper banks and seems to scurry away before t mounting storm.

BLACKNESS.  Then shafts of light become visible, above a  ridge of rock. Flatbed appears, trailing two heavy two cables.  Behind i the mass of Deepcore emerges from the darkness, its forwa lighting array blazing. Flatbed is towing it like a tug, aided by Deepcore's own  mighty stern thrusters.

Bud, his feet propped up, uses joystick controls to 'fly' Deepcore, maneuvering against currents and around seafloo obstacles.  He is guided by the side-scan sonar display,  with Hippy assisting in the sonar shack. Through the front viewport, Flatbed can be seen out ahead McBride appears on the bridge monitor, holding a sheet of weather-fax.
Well, it's official, sportsfans.   They're calling it Hurricane  Frederick, and it's going to be making  our lives real interesting in a few  hours.
Bud responds via video.
Fred, huh?  I don't know.  Hurricanes  should be named after women.
McBride looks up as the bridge door opens.  Lindsey enter in a blast of wind, wet as a wharf rat and twice as pisse off.  Maybe Bud is right.
Bud is surprised to see Lindsey's face appear on the moni screen.
I can't believe you let them do this!
(unpreturbed, almost  cheerful)
Hi, Lins.  I thought you were in  Houston.
I was, but I managed to bum a ride  on the last flight out here.  Only  here isn't where I left it, is it,  Bud?
Wasn't up to me.
We were that close to proving a  submersible drilling platform could  work.  We had over seven thousand  feet of hole down for Chrissake.  I  can't believe you let them grab my  rig!
Your rig?
My rig.  I designed the damn thing.
Yup, and Benthic Petroleum paid for  it.  So as long as they're hold the  pink slip, I go where they tell me.
You wimp.  I had a lot riding on  this.  They bought you... more like  least rented you cheap--
I'm switching off now.
Virgil, you wiener!  You never could  stand up to fight.  You-- Bud hits the switch and the screen goes dead.
Bye. Hippy looks over him, trying very hard not to crack up.
Virgil?
God, I hate that bitch.
Yeah, well you never should have  married her then. Bud nods fatalistically.

Ten foot waves crash through the launch-well, sending up  geysers of spray. Next to the launch-well, crewman have attached a lifting  cable to CAB THREE, eighteen feet of ugly yellow submersi It slams violently in its steel cradle as the drill-ship  rolls.  Coffey and Schoenick hand the gear bags in to Wil and Monk though the hatch under the rear of the submersib Lindsey approaches, wearing a borrowed roustabout's cover She looks down at the larger of the two equipment cases  brought by the SEALs, lying on the deck.  Stenciled on it are the words: F.B.S./DEEP SUIT/MARK IV. Coffey and Schoenick push past her to pick it up.

Let's go, gentlemen!  We either launch  now or we don't launch. Coffey looks up in surprise as she nimbly climbs the side Cab Three and grabs the lifting shackle, circling her rai hand to signal the crane man.

Take her up, Byron! Cab Three, with Lindsey riding its back, is pulled up out its cradle and starts to swing violently as Explorer pitc The submersible is then swung out to the center of the la well.  It sways and gyrates above the furious water below Lindsey drops into the upper hatch. 33   INT. EXPLORER BRIDGE/D.O.C. Kirkhill leans suddenly over the console to look out the  window.
What the hell is she doing out there?   Son of a bitch... (into microphone)
Lindsey... get out of Cab Three.   Bates is taking her down.
Lindsey pulls her headset as she dogs down the inside loc levers of the hatch.
Bates is sick.  Besides I've got  more hours in this thing than he  does. (to Coffey)

A little change of plan. The little sub is swinging like a pendulum on the cable, the SEALs, jammed in with their equipment in the tiny spa are getting slammed into the walls.  Lindsey is calmly  flipping switches as she talks.
Lady, we better fish or cut bait.
Just hold your water, okay? (to Kirkhill)
So Kirkhill, we gonna do this or we  gonna talk about it? 35   INT. EXPLORER BRIDGE/D.O.C. The plug is pulled on DeMarco's patience.
I don't care who drives the damn  thing.  Just get my team in the water.
Alright, alright.  Christ Almighty! He gestured dismissively to McBride.
Cab Three, you are clear to launch.
Lindsey reaches up a grabs a red lever.
Roger. (to Coffey)

There's only one way it's going to  happen... She pulls the lever hard.  CLUNK-CLANG!  The shackle-rele drops the sub. It freefalls ten feet to the water with an enormous splas and keeps right on going after Lindsey floods the trim ta Coffey et al have been slammed hard.
Touchdown.  The crowd goes wild.   Explorer... Cab Three.  We are  styling.

Roger, Cab Three. Lindsey cuts on the floodlights and maneuvers the descend submersible so that the umbilical cable is a few feet ahe on her front port.  Moving up through her lights, it will guide her down to the rig.  Cab Three free-falls into  increasing darkness.  Soon it is a candle below us in the indigo.

One Night is driving the tug one-handed, pouring coffee f a thermos and rocking out to the great truck-driving song "Willing" on the beat-box she's got propped up on the son rig.  Fighting white-line fever in the best tradition.
Bud and Hippy come in for a rousing chorus.
... I've been driving every kinda  rig that's ever been maaaaade...
Lit up like a proud Peterbilt, the rig crossed the trackl wastes.  We hear them singing, carried OVER.

In total blackness, the submersible descends along the  rigorous line of the umbilical cable.  Two hundred feet b it, the lights of Deepcore resolve out of the darkness. we can see the rig crawling over the ocean bottom like so monster lawnmower.
Deepcore, Deepcore... this is Cab  Three on final approach.
Gotcha, Cab Three.  Who is that?   That You, Lindsey?
Bud stop singing and snaps around at the mention of her n
None other. Bud's expression is nothing less than stricken.
Oh no... you gotta be kidding me.

Lindsey executes a 180 degree turn and cruises over the  control module, back through the A-frame toward the docki hatch.  The flange of Cab Three's lockout hatch settles o the pressure collar on the rig's back.  There is a CLUNK it mates up.

Lindsey drops down from the hatch into the small cylindri pressure chamber. The SEALs drop down behind her, passing their gear throug hand-over-hand. The chamber is spartan, with steel benches, a folding car table, breathing masks, and medical supplies.  Catfish gr them through the tiny porthole at one end.
Howdy, y'all.  Hey, Lindsey!  I'll  be damned!  You shouldn't be down  here sweet thing, ya'll might run ya  stockings.
Couldn't stay away.  You running  mixture for us?  Good.  Couldn't ask  for better.

Okay, here we go.  Start equalizing,  y'all. HISSSS of inrushing compressed gas.  The pressure in the  chamber rises.  The breathing mixture is composed of heli oxygen and nitrogen.  Catfish monitors it carefully from station outside the chamber, watching the gauges with a  practiced eye.  Lindsey and the SEALs all grab their nose and start making funny faces... popping their ears with t familiar diver's 'equalization' technique.  They continue as:
Get comfortable.  The bad news is we  got six hours in this can, blowing  down.  The worse news is it's gonna  take us three weeks to decompress  back to the surface later.
We've been fully briefed, Mrs.  Brigman.
Don't call me that, okay... I hate  that.  Alright, from now on we watch  each other closely for signs of  HPNS...
(as if by rote)
High-Pressure Nervous Syndrome.   Muscle tremors, usually in the hands  first.  Nausea, increased  excitability, disorientation.
Very good.  About one person in twenty  just can't handle it.  They go buggo.   They're no way to predict who's  susceptible, so stay alert.
Look, we've all made chamber runs to  this depth.  We're checked out.
Oh... chamber runs.  Uh huh, that's  good. (Coffey turn away)
Well, hey... you guys know any songs? They ignore her.  Start going over some diagrams of the  Montana's interior. It's going to be a long six hours.

Catfish checks his watch, then reaches over and adjusts a value on the tri-mix manifold, watching the gauges.   Satisfied, he leans over to the pressure window in the do checking out the SEALs.  Hippy has come down from the con deck for an advanced look are the interlopers.  Jammer is a chair, reading a Louis L'Amour paperback.
Those guys ain't so tough.  I fought  plenty of guys tougher'n them.
Now we get to hear about how he used  to be a contender. Catfish hold up one callused fist up in front of Hippy's  face.
You see this?  They used to call  this the Hammer.
Hippy wasn't born then.

It looks like the end of a long bus trip.  Everyone silen leafing through beat-to-hell magazines or just staring.   Lindsey has her feet propped up on the smaller of the SEA two equipment cases.  She casually toes open one of the  latches, then the other.  Glances at Coffey.  He's readin She begins to lift the lid with her toe.  Gets a GLIMPSE  INSIDE, of packing foam, and what looks like a SMALL BLAC METAL BOX.  Then... WHAM!  Coffey's foot comes down on th lid, slamming it shut.  Startled, she looks up into his c gaze.
Curiosity killed the cat.
TIGHT ON CATFISH'S hands... closing values... spinning th wheel on the chamber hatch.  CUT WIDER as it cracks open  with a virgin's sigh and swings aside.

Y'all'er done to a turn and ready to  serve.  Everybody okay? The SEALs nod peremptorily and shoulder their gear.  Lind exits first, followed by Monk, Wilhite, and Schoenick.  C bends to relatch the small equipment case.  He is alone f one moment in the chamber.  He raises his hand and stares it.  The fingertips are trembling the slightest bit.  He  clenches them into a fist and walks out.
As Lindsey emerges into the main corridor of the rig, she bumps into a large, dark mass.
Hey, was there a wall here before?   I don't remember a wall here.  Oh,  Jammer!  Hi. The 'wall' grins down to her.
Howdy, there, little lady. Coffey emerges behind them and, ignoring Lindsey, faces  Jammer.
(to Jammer)
Show us the dive prep area.  We need  to check out your gear. Jammer scowls, turns and leads the SEALs in the sub-bay. Catfish and Lindsey exchange a look.
Those guys are about a much fun as a  tax audit.
TIGHT ON HIPPY, bathed in the light of the sonar display. He is making kissing sounds at Beany, who has his inquisi nose right up to Hippy's lips.
Hippy, you're going to give that rat  a disease. WIDER, as Hippy and Bud to see Lindsey leaning in the doo She and Bud size each other up.  He opts for a jovial  approach, his eyes wary.
Well, well.  Mrs. Brigman.
Not for long. Lindsey crossed past him, her eyes scanning the banks of  equipment, almost unconsciously checking, checking... get the pulse of her big iron baby.
You never did like being called that,  did you?
Not even when it meant something. (looking through the  front port)
Is that One Night up in Flatbed?
Who else? Lindsey leans past Bud to the gooseneck mike on the conso
Hi, One Night, it's Lindsey.
One Night mimes a puking motion, finger down her throat. Then she replies with sickening sweetness...
Oh, hi, Lindsey.
Lindsey fives the sonar shack the once-over.  She tweaks  some knobs.
I can't believe you were dumb enough  to come down.  Now you're stuck here  for the storm...  dumb, hot-rod...  dumb.
Look, I didn't come down here to  fight. She crosses past Bud and exits into the corridor.  Bud bo out of the chair to follow her and Hippy scrambles in to  take over.
Bud catches up with Lindsey in the corridor, and through following keeps pace with here as she make here inspectio
Then why'd you come down? She stops abruptly to look at a leaky pipe.  He almost sl into her.  She moves on, climbing down the ladder to the  lower level.
You need me.  Nobody knows the systems  on this rig better than I do.  What  is something was to go wrong after  the Explorer clears off?  What would  you have done?

Wow, you're right!  Us poor dumb ol'  boys might've had to think for  ourselves.  Coulda been a disaster. On the lower level landing, Lindsey opens a hatch into on of the machine rooms.  ROAR OF PUMPS AND COMPRESSORS.
Lindsey enters and moves expertly through the dark labyri of pipes and roaring machinery.  Her eyes rove constantly over fittings, gauges, circuit panels.
(yelling)
You wanna know what I think?

In violent seas little hope remains  for over a hundred Russian crewmen  still missing after the sinking an  hour ago. SHOT OF AMERICAN CRUISER, burning, listing to one side in heavy seas. Replaced by SHOT OF NETWORK ANCHORMAN.
Soviet military spokesmen have claimed  that the collision constituted an  unprovoked attack.  This was denied-- It continues.  Bud looks at Lindsey.  She turns to him,  expression grim.
Bud, this is big time.

The divers are working head-first in the missile's launch tube.  Monk reads from a plasticized card, directing the  other two step by step.  The arcane litany is punctuated the hissing rasp of their breathing.
Separation sequencer disconnected.   Next?
Remove explosive bolts one through  six in counterclock-wise sequence.
Check... removing bolt one.
ON THE RIG CREW, watching.  Bathed in the light of the vi screen.
... just learned that Soviet  negotiators have walked out of the  strategic arms limitation summit in  protest over the incident this  morning. Bud switches the channel.
... US and NATO military forces have  been put on full alert worldwide  this morning in the wake of...

It's on every channel. Bud switches again.  Reception is getting worse as the st affect the satellite down-link to Explorer.  THE SCREEN s a reporter on a city street, stopping people at random.   Their answers are edited together:
You just feel so hopeless.  You can  see it coming, but what can you do?   What can anyone do?
Hey, they don't want war any more  than we do.  You think about it, you  say... hey, they love their kids  too.  So why are we doing this? He is replaced by a self-righteous, middle-aged woman.
If the Russians sank that submarine,  they deserve what they got and a lot  more, if you ask me, and you did.  I  think we've been pussyfooting around  with them long enough.

It is now clear what the SEALs are doing.  Using large li bags and Flatbed's big arm, they have pulled one of the  Trident C-4 missiles partway out of its launch tube, and  have partially disassembled the nose-shroud, exposing sev of the MIRV warheads within. Moving very carefully, Wilhite and Schoenick ease one of individual MIRVs out of its bracket.  Hanging under a lif bag in a jerry-rigged harness, the three-foot long warhea is move gently by the divers to the back of Flatbed.
Another man in the street interview, tortured by static.
Scared?  I'm scared ____-less.  But  if it happens it happens, nothing I  can do about it.  Right?  So why  think about it?

Flatbed surfaces in boiling foam.  The rig crew are all  waiting.  Like a crack pit-crew Bud's people leap onto Fl while its deck is still awash and start to work on the Na divers, unsealing their helmets and uncoupling their  umbilicals.  Hippy and Bud start to untie a cylindrical o wrapped in one of the SEAL's gear bags.  Coffey emerges f the hatch.
Don't touch that.  Just step away.   Now!
Excusez moi.
Coffey, we're a little pressed for  time.

Monk, Schoenick... secure the package. The two SEALs unlash the object in the black bag.  Bud an Lindsey exchange a glance.  He glares at Coffey as they p each other.  One Night nimbly climbs the hatch-tower and  drops in.  Bud swings the heavy hatch up, balancing it, a grins down at One Night.
This ain't no drill, slick.  Make me  proud.
Piece of cake, baby. He swings the hatch closed with a CLANG.

The big A-frame, massive as a railroad bridge, to which t umbilical from the Explorer is attached.  Flatbed rises I FRAME arcing around the coupling mechanism F.G.  One Nigh deploys the big hydraulic arm. It unfold from Flay bed like a huge steel spider leg, its claw-like 'gripper' opening.
An ALARM sounds stridently on the dynamic-positioning con
We're losing number two thruster.   Bearing's going.

Deep in one of the catamaran hulls, the positioning thrus motor is SCREAMING like a steel banshee above its usual r It EXPLODES with smoke and shrapnel.  A roaring fire erup Crewmen run shouting in the smoke.
Now a KLAXON is going off as the ship begins to slew in t high winds.
It's not holding.  We're swinging  out of position!
As the ship slews, the umbilical is drawn off vertical. goes tight as a bowstring.  Pulled to the edge of the lau well, it rips down the side with a godawful screech, tear loose ladders and floats.
Flatbed's manipulator has gripped the de-coupling mechani when the cable suddenly pulls taut.  The sub is jerked  sideways, its grip dislodged.  We see One Night get tosse around inside.

Lindsey is in the corridor with a cup of tea when the who rig BOOMS LIKE A GONG and lurches sideways.  She's wearin her tea when Bud tears through a doorway and goes poundin past her.  The intercom blares...
Bud to control!  Emergency!  Bud to  Control! Bud claws his way up the ladder to level two.  The rig BO and shudders as...
The rig begins to move. The enormous skid breaks loose.   Starts to slide, plowing furrows in the bottom.  One Nigh junks the controls, pivoting her submersible as the A-fra looms toward her.
Bud runs in, past Hippy, and grabs the mike.
Topside, topside... pay out some  slack, we're getting dragged!

The winch man staggers along the railing, blasted by 80-k winds.  He sprints for the base of the enormous crane whi supports the umbilical winch.  A wave blasts him into the bulkhead.  He half-crawls to the ladder going up to the w house.  As he climbs the winch's heave-compensator slides and down, FILLING FRAME behind him. It is bottoming-out with a sound like a piledriver, overl by the strain on the cable.  It chooses that moment to fa GRINDING CRASH OF METAL.
Lindsey has joined Bud, looking out the front viewport.
We're heading right for the drop  off!

The deck is ripped upward as the entire 40-ton crane is p over by the weight of Deepcore.  It topples in the launch well with a roar of tortured steel that rivals the storm. An EXPLOSION OF WATER.  UNDERWATER, the crane tumbles bet the twin hulls.  Trailing a vortex of foam and debris, it roars down on us, FILLING FRAME WITH BLACKNESS.
McBride stares in shock at the churning cauldron of the l well.  Grabs the underwater telephone.
Bud!  We've lost the crane!
What?  Say again.

head_text.subj: IT'S ON ITS WAY TO YOU

text: Everyone is stunned by what is happening.  Lindsey fires the sonar.
Got it!  It's dropping straight to  us. She puts the signal over the speakers and the room fills  with eerie PINGING. Bud shouts over the intercom.

Rig for impact!  Seal all exterior  hatches.  Move it!  Let's go! VARIOUS ANGLES, QUICK CUTS, as everyone runs to comply: The rig crew pounding down the narrow corridors.  Diving  through low hatchways.  Hatches are closed and the wheels spun down.  Hippy puts Beany into a ZIP-LOK BAG and seals it.

The umbilical drops down in slack loops out of the blackn above, draping itself over the habitat in large coils.  O Night pilots her submersible feverishly among the falling loops.  She banks and twists.  A length of heavy umbilica slams onto her neck, tipping the sub. She manages to get out from under it a keep going.

Through the front viewport they can see the coils of cabl piling up in front of the rig.  The hull booms with impac as the massive stuff hits. Everyone hold their breath as the sonar return-pings get  closer... and closer.  And closer... An ENORMOUS SHAPE plunges into the floodlight in front of the rig. K-WHAM!!  The 40-ton crane hits like a flatiron thirty fe in front of them. A clean miss.  Much WHOOPING AND CHEERING.  Then... The crane topples slowly over the back.  It rolls down th slope of the drop-off, gathering speed.  Then tumbles ove the cliff into the abyssal canyon. The coiled umbilical starts to pay out after it like rope after a harpoon. And they're still attached.
Oh shit. An agonizing few seconds.  Then... the cable pulls taut. K-BOOM!!  The rig is slammed by the shock.  Everyone is  knocked off his feet, into walls and equipment.

The rig begins to slide.  It tilts over the embankment an grinds down the slope of the drop-off in a cloud of silt. The cable pulling it inexorably toward the cliff.  The  framework twists and slams into rocks.  SCREECHING AND  GROANING of tortured steel.

All hell has broken loose.  SIRENS, SCREAMING, a KLAXON  HOOTING moronically. Bud sprints from Control, bouncing off the corridor walls the rig lurches and tilts.  The lights go out.  Emergency light come on.  He trips and falls, scrambles up, running on. IN THE LADDERWELL of trimodule C, Lindsey runs toward the machine rooms. K-BOOM!  A searing bright EXPLOSION in the electrical roo Flames roar through the doorway.  She dashes to a seawate hose hanging nearby and starts to unroll it.  She sees Co and Schoenick in maintenance, lashing down the mystery  package.
Hey!  Get on this hose, you turkeys!

Monk is working in a spray of seawater, turning valves to stop the flow of ruptured pipes.  Behind him, a wall of f blossoms through the door from the electrical room, drivi the back with the heat.  A reservoir-tanks breaks loose f one of the compressor assemblies.  In rolls at him, crush his legs against machinery.  The fire roars into the room

Hippy runs in.  The place is going nuts.  Water floods fr the moonpool as the rig tilts.  Wilhite is dancing across the deck, leaping over compressed-gas cylinders which are rolling around loose.  Cab One jumps clear off its cradle and slides SCREECHING across the deck.  Wilhite, running  before the 12-tom juggernaut, had no place to go.  The SE dives into the churning moonpool.  Cab One slams into the end wall, then spins and rolls toward Hippy. He starts to run.  Drop something.  Looks back. Beany, in his zip-loc bag, is lying in the path of the sl submersible. Hippy runs back.  Scoops up the baggie.  Cab One FILLS FR behind him. He makes it through the door an instant before the thing  hits behind him, buckling the steel doorframe.

Wilhite is clawing up the sheep skirting of the moonpool. He gets his fingers over the top.  Pulls himself up... A steel helium tank slams against his fingers, crushing t and he falls back.  More tanks bounce over the lip of the pool, hammering Wilhite down into the foaming water. He doesn't surface.
The rig is sliding to the edge of the cliff.  Beyond it.. the bottomless pit of the Cayman Trough.  It slams, crush and twisting, into a rock outcropping and stops, hanging  over the precipice.

Perry is trapped as the trimodule floods with stunning  swiftness.  He makes it through an emergency hatch betwee floors but can't get it closed.  The inrushing tide blast it open.  He scramble upward to the next hatch.  Spins th wheel.  No time.  He is slammed against the ceiling by th force of the water.

Lew Finler, Tommy Ray Dietz, and Lupton McWhirter fight t way toward the door as the drill room floods rapidly.  Ah the big automated watertight door is closing like a motor bank-vault.  They reach it just as it is closing, but can prevail against the strength of the motors.  FROM THE FAR SIDE, we can see them screaming soundlessly at the tiny  pressure window in the door.  We can hear the dull THUNK their pounding.

Coffey and Schoenick, in emergency breathing masks, are  fighting the fire with a seawater hose and fire extinguis Smoke and steam choke the dark chambers. Nearby, Lindsey grabs Hippy's arm as he is running past a drags him into the blazing compressor room.  Hands him he seawater hose.  Wide-eyes, he starts blasting everything sight with water.
No! Hold it on me! She rushed into the teeth of the fire as Hippy blasts her with a spray of water, following her into the intense hea
She grabs Monk, who is semiconscious, and drags him out o the blazing room... Hippy dancing back with the hose,  tripping, blasting her in the face. But it works.  They get Monk clear.

Bud comes pounding down the flooding corridor in time to the water in the rill room swirl above the pressure windo obscuring the faces of the trapped men.  He claws futilit at the door.  The motors and the fail-safe latching mecha are on the opposite side.  Through the pressure window he watches helplessly as they drown.  We don't see what he s but we know what he sees.  Suddenly the bulkhead next to gives way and a freezing torrent thunders in.  Bud is blo off his feet a hurled along the corridor. He scramble up somehow, splashing waist deep toward the  opposite end of the corridor where another of the hydraul doors is closing inexorably.  He's not going to make it. reaches it a moment too late to squeeze through. Grabs the edge of the door and desperately tries to stop from closing with the strength of this arms.  It doesn't  work.  The steel door closes on the fingers of his left h pinning them in the doorframe. But something amazing happens.  His wedding ring lodges  between the door and frame, preventing his fingers from b crushed and the door from sealing and locking. It resists tons of pressure, denting but not collapsing. The freezing sea pours in until only his head is clear.

Heeyy!!  HHHEEEYYY!! ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE DOOR, Catfish and Sonny come pou up.  They see his face at the tiny window and his hand ja in the door.  Sonny wedges a crowbar in the narrow openin and starts to pry.  Catfish whips open his jackknife and  slashes the hydraulic hoses on the door actuator.  He is  sprayed with red hydraulic fluid, machine blood. Together they force open the door.  Bud is blown through a torrent of water.  Sonny is thrown back into some pipes Breaks his arm. Together they somehow heave the door shut manually, cutti off the flow. Catfish hammers the fail-safe latch home with the crowbar
Bud lies gasping and shivering... staring at the tiny ban of metal that saved him.

LOOKING DOWN THE WALL of the canyon as Big Geek moves ben us, tilting up to show Deepcore perched at the very edge the abyss.  The rig is twisted and dented, covered with l of umbilical, trimodule-A a mass of wreckage. The ROV passes across the front of the control module.   Through the front port, two figures can be seen in the li of a single emergency lamp.
Mayday, mayday.  This is Deepcore  Two calling Benthic Explorer.  Do  you read, over?
Sonny flips some switches on the UQC acoustic transceiver Tries again.
Benthic Explorer, Benthic Explorer.   Do you read, over?  This is Deepcore--
Forget it, Sonny.  They're gone.

Bud walks down the corridor from control, slowly... as if carrying a great weight.  The air is still thick with smo The power off... everything lit by emergency lights.   Makeshift quarters have been set up in the mess hall, wit blankets laid out on the tables, and with folding cots in the storage room across the hall.  Jammer is still  unconscious.  Coffey and Schoenick bring Monk in on a  stretcher, and set him up on a table.  He is conscious bu dazed with painkillers, his led splinted.
Did you find Wilhite?
No. He and Bud lock eyes.  Bud bites back on his recriminatio but his gaze blames Coffey.  He turns away.
Brigman. (Bud turns)

I was under orders.  I had no choice. Coffey's manner is subdued, contrite.  A marked contrast his previous brusque arrogance.  He's wrestling with his loss, a sever blow to the tight brotherhood of a SEAL uni Bud's anger is not dispelled.  But he can't address it no He moves on. PAST THE INFIRMARY, where Sonny Dawson is rigging a sling over his own broken arm.  He cries out in pain, cursing a himself.  LOOKING DOWN THE CENTRAL WELL as Bud crosses.   Down through the grill decking we can see the bottom leve of the module is flooded.  Catfish is down there welding, sending shivering reflections through the chamber.
Lindsey is working, up to her knees in water.  She is cov with grease, tools scattered around.  Bud puts his hand o her shoulder.  She looks up, blows some hair out of her e
What's the scoop, ace?

I can get power to this module and  sub-bay if I remote these busses.   I've gotta get past the mains, which  are a total melt-down. Rather than trigger anger and invective, the disaster see to have affected her in a different way.  She's accepted situation, now that's it's done, and is immersing herself technical tasks, which are for her therapeutic.
Need some help?
Thanks.  No, I can handle it.  Bud...  there won't be enough to run the  heaters.  In a couple hours this  place is going to be as cold as a  meat locker.
What about O-2?
Brace yourself.
We've got about 12 hours worth if we  close off the sections we're not  using.
The storm's gonna last longer than  12 hours.
I can extend that.  There's some  storage tanks outboard on the wrecked  module.  I'll have to go outside to  tie onto them. She goes back to her task, working efficiently with a soc wrench.
Hey, Lins... (she looks up)
I'm glad your here.

Yeah?  Well I'm not. The sub bay is still a mess.  Dark.  A few battery-operat lamps.  Flatbed is back, floating in the moonpool. One Night and Hippy are in deep concentration, piloting t two ROVs in an image survey of the rig.  Bud comes up beh them, check her screen first. BIG GEEK'S MONITOR shows a view of the aft section of the rig.  The drilling derrick had collapsed across Cab Three totaling it.  A girder is jammed through its acrylic fron dome.
Right through the brainpan.  Deader'n  dogshit, boss.
(to Hippy)
Where're you?
Quarters.  Level two.
Little Geek rises up through the open central hatch, pivo in a circle to scan the flooded interior.
TIGHT ON VIDEO SCREEN, LITTLE GEEK'S POV.  The interior o the structure is a shambles.  The lights of the little ro fall upon a figure... Perry.  Lying on the deck, almost  looking like he's asleep.
That's Perry.
(lets his breath out  slowly)
That's it then.  Finler, McWhirter,  Dietz, and Perry.  Jesus.
(gestured at the screen)
Do we just leave him there?
Yeah, for now.  Our first priority's  to get something to breathe.

Catfish and Lindsey, in suits and helmets, drop down from the glare of the moonpool onto the dark sea floor under t rig.  Walking, they pull their umbilicals behind them and head out through the twisted wreckage.  Little Geek follo along like a dog at their heels.  They settle beside a va assembly at the base of the wrecked module.
Cat, you tie onto this manifold.   There's some tanks on the other side;  I'm gonna go check them out.

You watch yourself. He begins to attach one end of a coiled-up high-pressure  hose to a manifold. She takes the other end of the hose and moves off into th darkness.  Little Geek goes with her faithfully.
Cab One is hanging from the overhead crane while One Nigh works to repair it.
Bud is nearby, tending hose for the divers and handing he tools.  Talking while they work.  Hippy is across the moo running Little Geek.
Gimme a three-eighths socket on a  long extension. (he hands it to her)
So there you were--
There we were, side by side, on the  same ship, for two months.  I'm tool- pusher and we're testing this  automated derrick of hers.  So, we  get back on the beach and... we're  living together.
Doesn't mean you had to marry her.
We were due to go back out on the  same ship.  Six months of tests.  If  you were married you got a state- room.  Otherwise it was bunks.
Okay, good reason.  Then what?
It was alright for a while, you know.   But then she got promoted to project  engineer on this thing, couple years  ago.
She went front-office on you.  Tighten  that for me, right there.  That's  it.
Well, you know Lindsey, too damn  aggressive-- Son of a--!! He's jammed his fingers with a wrench torquing down a bol Whips his hand out.
She didn't leave me... she just left  me behind. She puts her arm around his shoulders, somehow managing t be fraternal, maternal and suggestive all at the same tim

Bud, let me tell you something.  She  ain't half as smart as she thinks  she is. She smiles and pretends to kink Lindsey's air-hose. ACROSS THE CHAMBER, Hippy scowls as Little Geek's screen  starts to go haywire with interference.
Hey, Lindsey, you reading me?  Over.

Catfish is working on one side of the wrecked module whil Lindsey is on the other, out of sight.  She is standing o the bottom at the base of the wreckage, checking valves o rack of oxygen bottles amongst the wreckage. Right at the edge of the canyon wall.  Behind her is a sh drop to nothingness

Yeah, Hippy, I read you.  What's the  matter? The reply is GARBLED by a wash of static.  Then, for no  apparent reason, Lindsey's helmet light begins to dim out Little Geek's lights fade.  His motors whine to a stop. ON CATFISH, as his lights drop to candleglows.
The emergency lights are dimming, like a brownout.  Bud g the diver intercom mike.
Lins, how're you doing?  Lindsey?
ON LINDSEY, as she fiddles with her lights and transceive pack.
Catfish... I got a problem here.   You there?  Catfish? Behind her, SOMETHING rises from the depths. It is the little vehicle she almost collided with at the  Montana wreck.

It comes right up behind her.  She doesn't know it's ther It hovers sideways like a hummingbird, as if curious, try to get a better look.  She becomes aware of the pulsing g on the ground around her.  She turns slowly.  We see her  react as the glowing, pulsing apparition is reflected in faceplate. A more powerful glow washes up onto her from below.  Her  eyes go down.  She gasps, absolutely stunned... Above the edge of the wall, AN ENORMOUS SHAPE RISES SILEN OUT OF THE DEPTHS.  Over sixty feet across.  It looks lik blown glass manta ray, its transparent outer hull housing interior structures of great delicacy and complexity, pul with a blue-violet glow. Lindsey stand before it, unable to move.  Absolutely rapt Captivated by its ethereal beauty.  It begins to turn,  majestically, one rounded wing passing only a few feet ab her.  She reaches up.  Touches it as it passes over her. Lindsey is without fear, completely mesmerized. The thing completes its turn and dives gracefully down al the wall.  She is gently lifted by a backwash of turbulen water. About that time, Lindsey remembers she has a still camera little Nikonos. She fumbles to set focus and exposure with her bulky glov as the beautiful machine glides into the depths.  Gets al set for a shot and... WOOSH!  The little 'scoutschip' whizzes past her from beh startling her. She completely misses the shot of the 'manta ship'.  She  pivots, trying to get a shot of the little one as it zig- zags down along the wall, fast as a meteor.  CLICK.  She a shot a second before it disappears. From around the flank of the rig module, Catfish appears. Their com-sets come backs to life, along with their light
You better not say you missed that.
Missed what?
TIGHT ON SLIDE STRIP.  Lindsey's fingertip in for scale. The shot is black with a little squiggle of light in the  center.  Pathetic.
Nice shot, Lins.
What is that?  You drop your dive  light? WIDER, SHOWING THE GROUP huddled around Lindsey who has h freshly-processed slide roll laid out on the pinball mach using it as a light table.
Come on, you guys... look, this is  the little one right here.  You can  see how it's kind of zigging around.
If you say so.  It could be anything.

I'm telling you what is there.  You're  just not hearing.  The impulses  somehow aren't getting from you ears  to your brainpan.  There's something  down there.  Something not... us. She looks around.  Sees a lot of skepticism in the eyes a her.
Y'all could be more specific.
Not us.  Not human.  Get it?   Something non-human, but  intelligent...
You mean like Coffey? Lindsey is reddening.  Despite her conviction, this is re hard.
A non-terrestrial intelligence.

Non-Terrestrial Intelligence.  NTIs.   Yeah, I like that better then UFOs.   Although that works too... Underwater  Flying Objects. Hippy is not really mocking her.  He's actually into it. But it has that effect.  Catfish is eyeing Lindsey like h never seen her before.
Are we talkin' little space friend  here?

Right on!  Hot rods of the Gods.   Right, Lins?  Hey, no really!  It  could be NTIs.  The CIA has known  about them for years.  They abduct  people all the time.  There was this  woman I knew in Albuquerque who--
Hippy, do me a favor... stay off my  side. Bud takes her firmly by the arm.  Heads her out into the  corridor.
Lindsey, will you step into my office  for a minute...
He propels her along the corridor, away from the mess hal doorway.  They face each other in the narrow space.
Jesus, Lindsey--
Bud, something really important is  happening here.
Look.  I'm just trying to hold this  situation together.  I can't allow  you to cause this kind of hysteria--
Who's hysterical?  Nobody's  hysterical!
They're talking across each other, not connecting.  Bud w and frustrated. Lindsey is cranked up with the afterglow of her encounter
All I'm saying is when you're hanging  on by your fingernails, you don't go  waving you arms around.
I saw something!  I'm not going to  go back there and say I didn't see  it when I did.  I'm sorry.
God, you are the most stubborn woman  I ever knew.
I need you to believe me, Bud.  Look  at me.  Do I seem stressed out?  Any  of the symptoms of pressure sickness,  any tremors, slurred speech?
No.

Bud, this is me, Lindsey.  Okay?   You know me better than anybody in  the world.  Now watch my lips... I  saw these things.  I touched one of  them.  And it wasn't some clunky  steel can like we would build... it  glided.  It was the most beautiful  thing I've ever seen. Bud is stilled by her intensity.  She moves close to him. Eyes alive and luminous.

It was a machine, but it seems almost  alive.  Like a... dance of light.   Bud, you have to trust me... please.   I don't think they mean us harm.  I  don't know how I know that, it's  just a feeling.
How can I go on a feeling?  You think  Coffey's going to go on you 'feeling'?

We all see what we want to see...  Coffey looks and he sees Russians,  he sees hate and fear.  Bud, you  have to look with better eyes than  that. Bud has been taking this all in.  His eyes tracking her f He closes his eyes, taking a deep breath.  It's so hard f him to do this, but...
I can't, Lindsey.  I'm sorry.  How  can I?

Coffey has Bud, Lindsey and several of the rig crew gathe for a little summit.  Lindsey is withdrawn, sitting far f the others, a self-imposed exile.  They're all wearing wa clothes and hugging themselves.  Their breath shows in th air.
I want 'round-the-clock manning of  the sonar shack and the exterior  cameras.  We need early warning if  the Soviet craft try another  incursion.
(rolling her eyes)

Gimme a break!  Coffey, these things  live three and a half miles down on  the bottom of an abyssal trench!   Trust me... they're not speaking  Russian. Coffey looks at her for a moment, then goes on as if she  hadn't spoken.
(to One Night)
Why haven't you finished repairs on  the hydrophone transmitter yet?
I was having my nails done. Coffey is sweating, despite the chill.  Keeps his hands  clenched in fists so they won't see how bad the tremors h gotten.
Get something straight.  You people  are under my authority--

Look, podner... we don't work for  you, we don't take orders from you,  and we don't much like you.  In  addition to which your momma dresses  you funny. Coffey's eyes are straight razors.  He slashes them from  face to face.  You can see him tightening up like a  clockspring, losing control of the situation in front of own men.  Bud defuses it.
'Fish'?
Yuh?
Take the first watch in sonar.  Hippy,  you handle the exterior surveillance.   One Night, see if you can get that  transmitter working for me, okay?
Gimme a couple of hours. HOLD ON COFFEY as everyone leaves.  Winding tighter.

Coffey and Schoenick are bending over the warhead.  They  have a small port removed and are attaching waterproof le from an ELECTRONIC DETONATOR.  The black box Lindsey glim earlier.  As the two SEALs work like surgeons, we see pas Coffey's shoulder to a hemispherical window behind him, w looks out into the perpetual blackness.  Something appear a goofy shark face. Big Geek rises silently in front of the port.  It moves a little, trying to get a peek over Coffey's shoulder.
Hippy is twiddling his joysticks, watching the screen lik ferret.

Come on... move to the left... just  a little more... come on, A.J. Squared  Away... that's it-- ON THE SCREEN, Geek's POV.  Coffey is blocking Hippy's vi of whatever it is they're working on.  Abruptly, be moves The warhead is lying there in plain sight, detonator wire hooked up.  Hippy's eyes bug out.  He knows exactly what is.
Pretty radical, guys.  Pretty radical. He hurries to the VCR and puts it into RECORD.
Video image of the SEALs working.  It FREEZES on a clear  view of the warhead.
Say hello to MIRV. Bud has his face right up to screen.  He frowns, skeptica

A moment later the bubble  implodes, and Coffey disappears in a bloody froth of chur water, air and glass shards.

Deepcore, this is Cab One.  We need  assistance, over.  Deepcore, this-- With a SEARING CRACKLE or arc-light, a power panel shorts out and everything goes black.
Well, that's that.
Wonderful. (looking around)

Over there.  It's the rig. A glow, beyond a rock promontory... like the lights of a  town just over the hill in the desert.
Good hundred yards, I'd say.

Yeah, but it's gonna take them a  while to find us.  We better get  this flooding stopped. He picks up his helmet and clicks on the light.  Using th thing like a bulky flashlight.  The water is really pouri in, spraying them like a shower...  almost two feet deep  already.
You see where it's coming in?
Somewhere behind this panel.  Hold  this. She takes the light and he tries to reach the burst weld, which is blocked by a steel switch panel and a bunch of  conduit.

Bud scans the cramped interior, feels around under the wa It's past his knees.

Nothing.  Son of a bitch.  All I  need's a goddamn crescent wrench. He grabs the panel in both hands and starts torquing on i trying to wrench it off the wall.  Heaves on it repeatedl Finally stops, panting.  He's breathing hard now, and it' not just effort.
Son of a bitch!
Calm down, Bud. A nervous edge in her voice now.  Bud's turning all aroun looking around for anything, trying to think fast.  Water to their waists.  The sea closing in.
Okay... okay.  We gotta get you out  of here.
How?
I don't know how!
We've only got one suit.
I know!  I know!  But we better come  up with something.

Aaargh!!  I'm freezing! She climbs up on the pilots seat, scrunching right up aga the ceiling, keeping as much of herself as possible out o the frigid water.  She's shaking all over with the cold, getting drenched from above by water pouring in.
Okay, look, you swim to the rig and  come back with another suit.
Seven, eight minute swim each way...  not enough time.  Look at this... (the rate of flooding)

Time I get back you'll be-- That stops the conversation for a second.  About two feet airspace left. Bud can't believe what this is coming down to.  They both stare at each other for a long moment. He makes a decision.  Starts pulling off his backpack.
Alright, put this on.
What, you growing gills all of a  sudden?  You got it on, keep it on.
Don't argue, goddamnit, just--
No way!  Forget it.  Not an option. Bud has his pack off uncoupling it.  She keeps fighting h hands, stopping him, hooking it back up.  The desperation the situation fuel the struggle.
Lindsey, just put the thing on and  shut up--
NO!!  Now be logical, Bud, you're--
They're both right up against the ceiling, water up to th chests. Lindsey's lips are blue and trembling from the cold.
Listen... will you listen to me for  a second!?  You've got the suit on  and you're a better swimmer than me.   Right?  So I got a plan...
What's the plan?
I drown, you tow me back to the rig--

head_text.subj: WHAT KIND OF PLAN IS THAT

text: Lindsey's gut-scared... shaking violently, her eyes wide. But she's keeping it together.  Thinking it out.  Bud see the bottomless pit opening to take her and he can barely  think.

Look, this water is only a couple  degrees above freezing.  I drown.  I  go into deep hypothermia...  my blood  like icewater.  I can maybe be revived  after ten, fifteen minutes.  You got  all the stuff to do it on the rig. Bud stops moving and looks into her face, inches from him The water is up to their necks.  He knows that, as always infuriatingly, Lindsey is right.
It is insane.
It's the only way, Bud.  Now trust  me. She takes a deep breath.  Before her nerve fails she busi her hands on his suit, rehooking everything.
Jesus, I don't believe this is  happening. She raise his helmet.  Water up to their chins.  They loc eyes, inches apart.  He can feel her breath on his face.. maybe for the last time.
Oh God, Lins... I--

Tell me later. He grabs her head in both hands and pulls her mouth to hi They lock together in a fierce kiss, fueled by passion an terror... the naked realization of love hanging over the  abyss of death. She breaks away at the last possible second and quickly p his helmet over his head.  Seats is down over the neck ri
Lock the bail-out handle, sealing it.  Even with her head pressed up into the highest point of the ceiling, Lindsey mouth is barely above water.  She give a scared little la
This is maybe not such a great plan,  is it? She is half-paralyzed with the cold, shaking pathetically Puts her face to the glass of his helmet.  Seconds to go.

Hold me.  Hold me, Bud... I'm so  scared... He can't hear her, but he read her lips.  They clutch eac other desperately. The embrace last while the water rises over her mouth and nose.  She starts to choke.  Her hands grip his shoulders like claws.  She bucks and thrashes. Bud holds her, and a scream tears loose from him, a pure  agony of the soul.

The freezing seawater races into her lungs.  Her finger g slack, and her hands float lifelessly. Bud stares, transfixed, as the last tiny bubble trickles of Lindsey's open mouth.  He kicks himself into gear, fin frenzied as he spins the wheel of the lockout hatch.
TIGHT ON VIDEO SCREEN, one of the outside cameras.  A gho figure swims out of the darkness, towing something.
It's Bud.  Oh my God... that's  Lindsey!
Deepcore, Deepcore, do you read?
Read you, Bud.  We're here.

Bud swims with long, powerful kicks, towing Lindsey.  Her arms and legs float as gracefully as seaweed waving in a  gentle current.  Bud's voice comes in short rasps, breath hard, but icy with control.
Go to the infirmary... get the cart...  oxygen...  de-fib kit... adrenaline  in a... ten cc syringe... and some...  heating blankets.  You got all that?
Got it. Over.
Meet me in the moonpool.  Move fast.

The door crashes open and Jammer thunders in.  He picks u the CPR cart, meant to roll on wheels, and carries it out past Hippy, Catfish, and One Night, who are crowding in t get the rest of the equipment.  They ransack the place in about ten seconds, grabbing everything they might need an half of everything else.
Bud moves up toward the rectangle of light, towing Lindse to the diving platform.  Through the surface we can see t others arrive at the edge, looking down.
Hippy and Catfish are setting up the cart and the oxygen  kit, dropping things, making mistakes.  One Night is teac herself how to fill a syringe from a bottle of adrenaline

Here he comes! Jammer and Sonny leap into the freezing water, waist deep the submerged diving platform.  Bud bursts to the surface Together they haul Lindsey across the platform, out of th water, and onto the deck.  Her skin is blue-white, her ch still. Bud rips his helmet off in a near-frenzy, like a man  possessed, a man with a mission.  The others are galvaniz by his energy even though they all see Lindsey as dead, a corpse... cold and inert.  Water flows from her mouth and nose and her lips are blue, her limbs completely limp.
Hippy peels back one eyelid, to find the pupil fixed and  dilated. But when Bud shouts for them to move, they move.

Turn her over! They flip his wife's body over.  He straddles her, pushin down with both hands in the middle of her back.  Seawater gushes from her slack lips.  He does it again until the f stops, then flips her onto her back.

Come on, hurry!  Gimme the de-fib... One Night and Catfish are fumbling with the emergency car equipment.  They've all been trained in CPR and use of th gear but that was years ago, and this is a friend they're working on.  They're all thumbs.  Catfish drops the  electrodes, picks them up quickly, hands them to Bud...
Here, here, here... no, you got to  have bare skin, or it won't... Bud rips into her clothing, opening her jumpsuit, literal tearing away her T-shirt, revealing her bare chest... bon and still.
Jesus.  Gimme those, come on.   Catfish, move it, man!  Come on...  come on! He slaps the things into Lindsey's bare skin, one on the  sternum and one on the side of the rib cage.
Is that it?  Is this right?
Yeah!  I mean, I don't know... it  looks right.

All right.  Do it! One Night hits the switch and Lindsey's body convulses. is a pure muscle reflex, and when it is over, there is no hint of life.  Hippy pushes him back and puts a black rub oxygen mask over her mouth.  He opens the valve on the  cylinder and starts pumping the squeeze bag.
They start packing electronic blankets around her to figh the intense hypothermia

Do it again, One Night.  Zap her  again! The current hits Lindsey again and her back arches.  Bud  doesn't wait for a result... he's in his own reality now, driven.  He's doing it all at once, somehow, in a sensele frenzy... pumping on her chest with his hands, squeezing oxygen bag, placing the electrodes.
Aw.  Christ... come on, baby.  Again!   Do it again! Lindsey's back arches.  Her body relaxes, inert.

Come on, One Night... what are you  waiting for? A hush seems to have fallen over the group.  They know  instinctively that it's over.  But Bud can't accept it. looks at them, beseechingly, like they are somehow  intentionally holding out on him.  One Night starts to cr quietly.
(gently)

Bud, it's over, man.  It's over. There is a beat of silence.  Bud stares down into Lindsey half-open, motionless eyes. TIGHT ON LINDSEY'S EYES, moving in until the pupil FILLS  FRAME, a black void. REVERSE, HER POV.  SILENCE.  A distant, distorted image, see Bud, One Night, Jammer, Hippy, Catfish, staring down. It is like the circular top of a dark well, their faces  shimmering as if through the surface of water.  It is as we are in a well, descending, looking up at a circle of f growing smaller as we drop away... smaller and smaller,  receding until it becomes a point of light in the void, l the fading bright dot at the center of a turned-off TV. TIGHT ON BUD, rigid, staring.  Catfish puts his hand gent on Bud's shoulder. Suddenly Bud tears Catfish's hand away and sets upon Lind like a madman, renewing his efforts in spades... totally  manic.
No!  NO!  She's not... her heart is  strong, she wants to live... can't  you see that?  Come on, Lins.  Come  on, baby!  Zap her again!  Do it...
They do.  And Bud works, feverishly.  He lock his lips ov hers and starts mouth-to-mouth.  It is frantic, passionat the kiss of life.
Come on, breath!  Goddamn it, you  bitch, you never backed down from  anything in life... now fight! He slaps her face, hard.  Her head lolls.  He smacks her other way.

Fight, Goddamnit! LINDSEY's POV, from the bottom of the great well.  The ci of faces and light rockets toward us in the blackness, as soar upward from the pit.  We see Bud yelling, but his vo is distant, windlike.

TIGHT ON LINDSEY, still.  Then something incredible happe Something they will never forget as long as they live.   Lindsey coughs once, weakly, and her hands clench in a sp Bud see it and his expression becomes beatific.

Come on, Lins.  You can do it...  fight your way back, baby... The others look on in wonder as Bud wills this woman back She starts to cough, weakly at first... then more violent as she draws air into her lungs.  Bud crouches over her,  rubbing her limbs... trying to re-establish circulation. is like a difficult birth.  Lindsey comes hacking and how back into the world, wet and naked and fighting for breat Bud puts the oxygen mask over her face and she draws brea after agonized breath.  He pushes her wet hair back from face with his trembling hands, and watches her breathe.   Color is returning to her skin as she lies there, gasping weakly.
ONE THE GROUP... Catfish, Hippy, One Night, Jammer, the  others... they're all grinning, crying, beaming... gazing the miracle of her rebirth. ON BUD... tears are streaming down his face.
(a whisper, fierce  and harsh)
You did it, ace.

TIGHT ON LINDSEY, sleeping peacefully.  WIDER shows Bud  hovering over her, attentive.  They are alone in Bud's ti cubicle.  Perhaps twenty minutes have passed.  She is  completely swaddles in blankets, except for her face, and looks like a waif. Lindsey's eyes flutter and open.  The first thing she see is Bud, bending over her.  He can't help himself.  The te break again and roll down his cheeks.  She seems terribly fragile, but bright and aware.  She smiles, faintly... to his cheek.
Hey... big boys don't cry, remember?
Hi, lady.
Hi, tough guy.  I guess it worked,  huh?
'Course is worked.  You're never  wrong, are you?  How d'you feel.
I've been better.  Next time it's  your turn, okay? Bud's expression turn inexplicably grim.
Well, you got that right.

TIGHT ON BUD'S EYES, as Monk's fingers insert acrylic scl lenses under his eyelids so he can see in the fluid helme WIDER reveals Bud is wearing the SEALs' deep suit.  Every is grouped around, buckling and zipping.  He is  hyperventilating with an oxygen mask, part of the procedu for transitioning from air to fluid breathing.  Monk, on stretcher, is presiding.  The resident expert.  Lindsey i wrapped in a blanket, still looking wan and frail.  She  doesn't have the strength to resist Bud's will, but she's trying.
No, Bud, no... not you.

Who then? She looks around at the others.  Sees their eyes.  The fe Has her answer. He lowers the helmet over his head.  Catfish clamps it do We see what's riving him... his sense of responsibility f these people, for not being able to prevent this situatio He touches her cheek, one last time.  She sees his finger are trembling. Then he puts on the gloves.  Catfish is strapping a KEYPA UNIT onto Bud's forearm.  Lindsey wants to scream... to s this madness.
So I'll hear you, but I can't talk?
The fluid prevents your larynx from  making sound.  It'll feel a little  strange.
Warning you now, folks, I'm a lousy  typist. (a beat)
The moment of truth, huh? His breathing is shallow and tense.  He looks at Lindsey. The eyes of a condemned man.  She squeezes his hand.  He  takes a deep breath.
Okay.  Let's rock and roll.
Monk gently cracks a valve on the suit's feed line.  The  breathing fluid (3M fluorocarbon emulsion FX-80) swirls i the helmet.  Bud reflexively raises his chin.  The liquid fills toward his mouth.

Relax now, Bud.  Just keep breathing  as it fills... don't fight it.  Take  it in.  Just let yourself take it  in. Suddenly, there's nothing in there to breathe but liquid. His eyes go wide, instant panic.  He starts to thrash.  C heaving.

Hold him.  Hold him.  This is  normal... it'll pass in a second.   You're gonna be okay.  We all breathe  liquid for nine months, Bud.  Your  body will remember. Lindsey grabs Bud's shoulders, steadying him.  He finds h eyes, the look calming him.  He's passed into a realm fro which she has already returned. His spasms subside.  He begins to "breathe" normally.  He gets a goofy look of wonder on his face, not really belie what he's experiencing.  He is alive, alert and quite  completely drowned inside the FBS helmet.  He grins. Gives a big thumbs up.  Lindsey picks up a microphone.
Can you hear me okay? (another thumbs up)
Try your keypad. Bud taps out a brief message.  FEELS WEIRD - YOU SHOULD T THIS prints out on their portable monitor.
I already have, moron. They help Bud to the edge of the dive platform.  Jammer a Hippy lower Little Geek into the water and Bud grabs onto it.  Hippy yells right up next to his helmet.
I redid Little Geek's chip the same  as Big Geek!  He should take you  right to it.  All you gotta do is  hang on!
Lindsey crouches at the edge to watch Bud submerge. He looks up at her as he drops away. In a few seconds, she can't see him.  Her chin quivers,  minutely.

FROM FAR BELOW, Deepcore is a faint tiara of lights, abov in the blackness. A single moving light appears above, at the edge of the c and starts down.  It grows large, resolving into Bud, fre falling down the wall. He gathers speed as Little Geek's vertical thruster drive them down. Bud looks down.  Between his feet he can see a short way  down the wall in the glow of his single light, and beyond that an unfathomable blackness.  The wall unrolls upwards out of the darkness like a convoluted gray drapery.  He l up.  The lights of Deepcore are gone.  He feels  more alo than he has ever felt.  He types out:  CANT SEE YOU

We're right here with you, Bud.   Your depth is 3800 feet.  You're  doing fine. Bud comes upon the twisted wreckage of the crane, hanging against the wall like a forty-ton yo-yo at the end of the umbilical.
Everyone is grouped around the monitor screen, watching B telemetry.  Bud types out: GOOD DEAL ON SLIGHTLY USED CRA They watch the depth meter counting down.
4800 feet.  It's official.

Bud, according to Monk here, you  just set a record for the deepest  suit dive.  Bet you didn't think  you'd be doing this when you got up  this morning. The screen print out:  CALL GUINESS.  They laugh.  So far good.  Seconds later...
One mile down and still grinnin'.

WIDE SHOT.  Bud is a tiny spider dropping down the wall i pathetic little pool of light.  The wall is sterile brown gray, devoid of life at this depth. LOOKING DOWN, as the light shrinks to a star and vanishes the blackness yawning below.
Lindsey has the microphone gripped tightly, and the light in her voice is a bit brittle.
8500 feet, Bud.  Everything okay?
Ask him about pressure effects.   Tremors, vision problems, euphoria.
Ensign Monk want to know how you  feel. ON THE SCREEN, printing out: COLD.
Big baby. Then:  HANDS SHAKING.  HHARD TO TYPE.
It's starting.  It hits the nervous  system first.
Keep talking, Lindsey.  Just let him  hear your voice.  It doesn't matter  what about.
Don't forget Bud, you're being graded  on spelling as well as sentence  structure, so concentrate, okay? (long pause)
Bud, I... uh, there's some things I  want to say. It's hard for me.  I'm  not of those softy, gooey-center- type people.

It's not easy, you know, being a  cast-iron bitch.  It takes discipline  and years of training.  A lot of  people don't appreciate that. Lindsey has somehow tuned out the others in the room.  In her mind she is with Bud, out in the darkness.

But is wasn't all bad.  I know that.   You remember that bike trip... we  rode the Honda up through Oregon?   It took me a week to get my hair  untangled, but I've never been  happier.  It was the most... free...  I've ever felt.  I'm sorry I can't  tell you these things to your face.
Bud is visibly trembling, gritting his teeth... holding o as the vise-grip of pressure takes him.
It's pitiful.  I have to wait until  you're freezing in the dark and  there's ten thousand feet of water  between us.  I guess I'm babbling.   I'm sorry. Bus struggles with his keyboard.
Somehow's she's smiling and on the verge of tears at the  same time.
Two miles down and still grinnin'   Comin' up on the big ten thou'.
Bottom's still a mile and a half  down.
BLAM!  Bud jerks as his dive light implodes.  He still ha Geek's floodlights. He falls on.
12000 feet.  Jesus, I don't believe  he's doing this.
Shut up, Hippy.  Bud, how you doing? He types: SE LUMINUS THINNGS Everyone snaps suddenly aler
Uh, oh...
What kind of luminous things, Bud?
Maybe it's... you know... them. The screen prints out:  ITS OK. SQUID. GLOWING SQUID.

Bus is in an enormous school of bioluminescent squid,  graceful, attenuated creatures less than a foot long.   Thousands of then glide in ghostly arcs around him, filli the black void as far as the eye can see.  He stares at t in wonder.  Reaches out and touches one, catches it, lets go.  Are they really here?  He can no longer be sure of h own perceptions.
Another message from Bud:  THINK THEYR REAL.
He's losing it.  Talk to him.  Keep  him with us.
Bud, it's the pressure.  Try to  concentrate.  Concentrate on my voice.   Just listen to my voice.

Bud emerges from the school of squid.  As he falls, they  form a luminous plane of swirling colors above him.  He s upwards, transfixed.  BUD'S POV, the ghostly blizzard of  luminescence above him.  A spectral form takes shape in t patternless glow... resolving into Lindsey's face, a hund feet wide.  Gazing down at him, her expression sad.
Her image receded away from him into the darkness above a he falls. DOWN ANGLE ON BUD, reaching up in anguish.
Lindsey watches as Bud haltingly types out:  YOUR GOING A
I'm not going away, Bud.  I'm right  here, right here with you.  This is  Lindsey, Bud.  I'm right here.
Signal's fading.

We're losing juice... kill everything  we don't need.  Catfish, knock out  those lights. Everyone hustles to comply.  The room is plunged into  darkness, the faces of the group lit only by the ghostly screen.
Run it through the digital processor,  cook it as much as you can.
Seventeen thousand feet.  Good Christ  Almighty, this is insane.

Bud is shaking violently, as if with palsy.  His eyes kee rolling back, and he's having a hard time staying conscio He tries to type a message and he can't.  The tons of pre per square inch are short-circuiting his nervous system. Suddenly K-BAM!  Little Geek's pressure hull implodes.  I lights go out.  BLACKNESS.
Little Geek just folded.
Bye, little buddy.
He can still make it.

I know how alone you feel... alone  in all that cold blackness... but  I'm there in the dark with you, Bud  you're not alone... Lindsey seems not to be in the room, but to be with him,  seeing what he sees. She is oblivious to the others.

Blackness.  Then a bright light appears... he's lit a  MAGNESIUM FLARE. It's fierce, flickering glare lights his plunge.  Bud dis the stalwart little ROV and free-falls like a skydiver wi a chute.  Out of control, he hits a ledge and rolls off. Tumbles forward in a cloud of debris.  He hits another  outcropping, limp as a rag doll.  Rocks and sand rain dow with him as he continues his descent. Bud us quivering, teeth locked in a titanic rigor. He pulls his arms and legs slowly into a fetal position. In the plunge toward death he has gone he has gone full  circle, returned to the womb in which we all breathe the  water of life before we know the world of air and light. Still, there is Lindsey's voice, faintly in his helmet.
